intro: Mahurea speciosa, commonly known as the golden sandalwood, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Burseraceae family and is characterized by its aromatic, fragrant wood and distinctive leaves. The plant typically grows as a small to medium-sized tree, reaching heights of up to 15 meters. Its flowers are small and yellowish, often clustered in panicles, and it produces small, round fruits that contain a single seed. Due to its valuable timber and ornamental qualities, Mahurea speciosa is often cultivated in horticultural settings.
